# üí∞Ô∏è Marko: The 20-Year-Old German Developer Who Grew an AI Tool to $50,000/Month in Revenue and Sold It for Over $1 Million

Hello! I‚Äôm Yuma Ueno().

I‚Äôm struggling to build many products (Ex: AI-Powered Japanese FlashCards).

I‚Äôve researched the amazing indie hackers / entrepreneurs and summarized what they‚Äôve done.

I would like to introduce the great entrepreneur ‚ÄúMarko Kraemer‚Äù!

A genius developer born in Germany who, at just 20 years old, sold an AI product for over $1 million. His level of action and drive from a young age is so extreme it‚Äôs mind-blowing. Let‚Äôs take a look at his story! [...] ## üë¶ Hooked on Minecraft Since Childhood, He Started a Business Using His Programming Skills

His talent as an engineer and entrepreneur was visible from a very young age. In elementary school, he was completely hooked on Minecraft, playing it every single day. In the process, he picked up knowledge of graphic design and programming. He used this knowledge to build websites for Minecraft.

Following that path, at the age of 13, he founded a small agency called Blue Page. He started building and selling landing pages to local businesses. He‚Ä¶

Kraemer's entrepreneurial journey began unusually early. At just 12, he founded BluePage, building marketing landing pages for small businesses in Frankfurt, Germany. By 14, he had launched GastroPage, a restaurant digitization platform featuring QR-code menus, years ahead of the pandemic that would make such tools ubiquitous. Operating legally as a minor in Germany‚Äôs tightly regulated business environment required special court permission, an extraordinary exception granted to Marko. While still in high school, he went on to launch Plutus, a software development studio. ‚ÄúI essentially missed the last two years of school,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúDuring COVID, [...] With a newly approved O-1 visa, Marko now splits his time between San Francisco and Europe as he scales Kortix‚Äôs broader vision: helping organizations transition from human to AI-driven knowledge work through both self-serve tools and enterprise-grade implementations. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building for a future where AI agents can perform 70 to 80 percent of knowledge work,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt just automation. It‚Äôs a foundational shift unlike anything the labor market has seen before.‚Äù At just 20 years old, Marko's journey from teenage entrepreneur to AI visionary stands as a testament to his belief that innovation has no age limit, and that the future belongs to those who build it. [...] the last two years of school,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúDuring COVID, a friend managed my Microsoft Teams login so I could focus on building the company. I only showed up for the exams.‚Äù After graduating in 2023, Marko founded Kortix with an ambitious mission to build the foundational infrastructure for the AI revolution. The first product, SoftGen, an AI-powered web app builder, scaled from zero to $50K in monthly recurring revenue within four months and was acquired by a private equity firm. His current focus is Kortix Suna, an open-source platform he describes as ‚ÄúWordPress for AI agents.‚Äù In just weeks after launch, Suna amassed 50,000 users, earned 14,000 GitHub stars, and sparked serious enterprise interest with over 200 enterprise bookings. # üí∞Ô∏è Marko: The 20-Year-Old German Developer Who Grew an AI Tool to $50,000/Month in Revenue and Sold It for Over $1 Million

Yuma Ueno

12 min read

¬∑

Oct 21, 2025

--

Hello! I‚Äôm Yuma Ueno().

I‚Äôm struggling to build many products (Ex: AI-Powered Japanese FlashCards).

I‚Äôve researched the amazing indie hackers / entrepreneurs and summarized what they‚Äôve done.

I would like to introduce the great entrepreneur ‚ÄúMarko Kraemer‚Äù!

A genius developer born in Germany who, at just 20 years old, sold an AI product for over $1 million. His level of action and drive from a young age is so extreme it‚Äôs mind-blowing. Let‚Äôs take a look at his story! [...] ## üë¶ Hooked on Minecraft Since Childhood, He Started a Business Using His Programming Skills

His talent as an engineer and entrepreneur was visible from a very young age. In elementary school, he was completely hooked on Minecraft, playing it every single day. In the process, he picked up knowledge of graphic design and programming. He used this knowledge to build websites for Minecraft.

Following that path, at the age of 13, he founded a small agency called Blue Page. He started building and selling landing pages to local businesses. He‚Ä¶

results.content: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at the beginning of the largest workforce transition in human history, where 80% of knowledge work shifts from humans to AI.‚Äù Marko O. Kraemer's entrepreneurial journey began unusually early. At just 12, he founded BluePage, building marketing landing pages for small businesses in Frankfurt, Germany. By 14, he had launched GastroPage, a restaurant digitization platform featuring QR-code menus, years ahead of the pandemic that would make such tools ubiquitous. Operating legally as a minor in Germany‚Äôs tightly regulated business environment required special court permission, an extraordinary exception granted to Marko. While still in high school, he went on to launch Plutus, a software development studio. ‚ÄúI essentially missed the last two years of school,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúDuring COVID, [...] With a newly approved O-1 visa, Marko now splits his time between San Francisco and Europe as he scales Kortix‚Äôs broader vision: helping organizations transition from human to AI-driven knowledge work through both self-serve tools and enterprise-grade implementations. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building for a future where AI agents can perform 70 to 80 percent of knowledge work,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt just automation. It‚Äôs a foundational shift unlike anything the labor market has seen before.‚Äù At just 20 years old, Marko's journey from teenage entrepreneur to AI visionary stands as a testament to his belief that innovation has no age limit, and that the future belongs to those who build it. [...] the last two years of school,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúDuring COVID, a friend managed my Microsoft Teams login so I could focus on building the company. I only showed up for the exams.‚Äù After graduating in 2023, Marko founded Kortix with an ambitious mission to build the foundational infrastructure for the AI revolution. The first product, SoftGen, an AI-powered web app builder, scaled from zero to $50K in monthly recurring revenue within four months and was acquired by a private equity firm. His current focus is Kortix Suna, an open-source platform he describes as ‚ÄúWordPress for AI agents.‚Äù In just weeks after launch, Suna amassed 50,000 users, earned 14,000 GitHub stars, and sparked serious enterprise interest with over 200 enterprise bookings.
